Problem:
Consider a linear transformation system defined by \\( y(t) = e^{At}x \\), where A is a constant matrix and x is an initial vector. Evaluate the effect of the transformation \\( g(z) = Cz \\), where C is another constant matrix, on the system.

If the transformation \\( g(z) = Cz \\) is applied to the vector \\( x \\) at time t = 0 and then the system evolves according to \\( y(t) = e^{At}x \\), will the state \\( y(t) \\) at t = T be transformed by C in the same manner as if \\( C \\) was not applied at the initial time?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( g(z) = Cz \\) initially changes the starting vector to \\( Cx \\). The evolution under the system \\( y(t) = e^{At}x \\) starting from \\( Cx \\) leads to \\( y(t) = e^{At}Cx \\), and by properties of matrix exponentials, this is not generally equal to \\( Ce^{At}x \\). The output depends intricately on C and A interactions.
